Award.AwardTitle: Long Term Studies of Climate Impacts: Sustaining Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services in Tropical Stream Ecosystems, Puerto Rico
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will examine how natural species assemblages are affected by climatic change, especially in those ecosystems where temperatures are already exceptionally warm and where precipitation varies greatly. In sub-tropical stream ecosystems, such climatic change may lead to major shifts in natural ecological communities and processes. These shifts can influence distributions of important freshwater stream insects that break down organic matter and filter out the bacteria and other suspended particulates. These insect species are critically important in maintaining clear water for recreational uses and municipal water supplies. Grounded in 25 years of studies in the Luquillo Experiment Forest in Puerto Rico, the proposed research will identify the main factors that affect spatial and temporal distributions of key stream species and their effects on processing organic matter in streams at different elevations within large drainage networks. The analysis will identify specific network locations and geomorphic features where particular species are most likely to be vulnerable (e.g., shallow depth, high temperatures, low dissolved oxygen, and lack of flow).

The project will benefit the public, policy makers, and water managers by providing an in-depth understanding of the effects of extreme variability of water flows on stream dynamics that influence water quality and locations of vulnerability. The project will also provide interdisciplinary learning experiences for students, especially Puerto Ricans, who will participate in developing the online learning modules. These interdisciplinary learning modules will illustrate concepts of climate-driven changes on biodiversity and the economic values of key species in sustaining reliable, high-quality clean water for multiple uses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the project are to synthesize existing long-term data on the distributions of freshwater macroinvertebrates within different locations across a tropical montane drainage network to determine the effects of disturbances such as floods and droughts. The effects of extreme variability in flows resulting from the combined effects of multiple hurricanes, tropical storm events, and prolonged dry periods on the biotic community can alter species interactions, water quality, and ecosystem processes. The results of these species interactions are to enhance water quality through bio-filtration of suspended organic particulates as well as breakdown of organic matter (dead leaves, algae, etc.).  These biotic processes provide high-quality drinking water for communities and enhanced water quality for recreational uses of tropical streams as well as local harvest of fish and shellfish. The sustainability of these biotic interactions under changing climatic extremes requires sufficient connectivity with coastal estuaries so these species a can migrate upstream and downstream during their complex life cycles. Their capacity for long-distance movements includes adaptations for traveling many miles inland within river drainages. In many cases, they also seek refuge from fish predators at lower elevations by having post-larvae that can climb high, steep waterfalls (from 10 to 30 m high). These migratory routes can be disrupted by poorly designed dams built to generate hydropower.  The trade-offs between high connectivity of river habitats to sustain these species and the loss if dams are constructed in the wrong locations or by using inappropriate, non-function by-pass structures. Our results indicate that "off-channel dam" construction is much less disruptive than "run-of river dams" that previously were widely considered appropriate. In addition, this study further establishes the importance of intact, diverse riparian forests that provide important food resources to stream food webs from inputs of diverse, high-quality organic matter that falls into the stream at different times of year. This research integrates the effects of different locations under a wide range of conditions to convey the importance of evaluating options for sustaining the native biodiversity that ensures ecological processes continue for maintaining essential ecosystem services, such as clean freshwater.
